band_mbps.notes: Maximum theoretical 24 Mbps downstream, 3.3 Mbps upstream. Actual speeds highly dependent on line quality and distance.

delay_ms.notes: Increases with network congestion and distance.

queue_pkts.notes: Buffer size varies by equipment manufacturer.

band_mbps.notes: Modern GEO satellite services offer improved bandwidth over older systems.

delay_ms.notes: Physical limitation due to distance to geostationary orbit (35,786 km).

jitter_ms.notes: Atmospheric conditions and satellite movement contribute to variability.

band_mbps.notes: Highly dependent on signal strength, congestion, and carrier implementation.

delay_ms.notes: Increases with network congestion and distance from tower.

loss_percent.notes: Higher in areas with poor coverage or during handovers.

queue_pkts.notes: Larger buffers to handle mobility and varying signal conditions.

jitter_ms.notes: Increases during handovers and in congested networks.

band_mbps.notes: Highly dependent on distance from DSLAM, with significant degradation beyond 1km.

delay_ms.notes: Lower latency than ADSL due to improved technology.

loss_percent.notes: Improved error correction compared to ADSL.

queue_pkts.notes: Optimized buffer sizes for improved performance.

jitter_ms.notes: More stable than ADSL with less variation.

band_mbps.notes: Carrier aggregation enables higher speeds than standard LTE.

delay_ms.notes: Improved latency over standard LTE through protocol optimizations.

loss_percent.notes: Improved error correction compared to standard LTE.

queue_pkts.notes: Similar buffer sizes to standard LTE.

band_mbps.notes: Significant variability based on Speedtest measurements from 2023-2024.

delay_ms.notes: Satellite handovers occur approximately every 15 seconds, causing latency spikes.

loss_percent.notes: Higher than original estimate; packet loss primarily occurs during satellite handovers.

queue_pkts.notes: Deep buffers to accommodate satellite handovers.

jitter_ms.notes: Average variation between RTT intervals, with spikes during handovers.

band_mbps.notes: Dependent on number of bonded channels and network congestion.

loss_percent.notes: Modern cable systems have improved error correction.

queue_pkts.notes: Larger buffers to handle shared medium contention.

band_mbps.notes: Highly dependent on channel width, spatial streams, and client capabilities.

delay_ms.notes: Increases with distance from access point and interference.

loss_percent.notes: Higher in environments with interference or at range edges.

queue_pkts.notes: Large buffers to handle varying wireless conditions.

jitter_ms.notes: Increases with network congestion and interference.

band_mbps.notes: Dependent on spectrum allocation, signal strength, and network implementation.

loss_percent.notes: Advanced error correction provides improved reliability.

queue_pkts.notes: Optimized buffer sizes for low-latency applications.

jitter_ms.notes: More stable than 4G but still affected by network conditions.

band_mbps.notes: Overhead reduces theoretical 1000 Mbps to practical ~940 Mbps.

delay_ms.notes: Extremely low latency for local connections.

loss_percent.notes: Negligible packet loss in properly functioning networks.

queue_pkts.notes: Large buffers to handle traffic bursts.

band_mbps.notes: Extremely high bandwidth but limited by range and obstacles.

delay_ms.notes: Ultra-low latency when signal conditions are optimal.

loss_percent.notes: Higher loss rates due to sensitivity to obstacles and weather.

jitter_ms.notes: Increases significantly when signal is obstructed.

band_mbps.notes: Ranges from 500 Mbps to 10 Gbps depending on service tier.

delay_ms.notes: Extremely low latency for residential connections.

loss_percent.notes: Negligible packet loss in properly functioning networks.

queue_pkts.notes: Large buffers to handle traffic bursts.

band_mbps.notes: Overhead reduces theoretical 10000 Mbps to practical ~9400 Mbps.

delay_ms.notes: Extremely low latency for local connections.

loss_percent.notes: Negligible packet loss in properly functioning networks.

queue_pkts.notes: Very large buffers to handle high-bandwidth traffic bursts.

delay_ms.notes: Significantly improved latency over previous Wi-Fi generations.

loss_percent.notes: Improved reliability through OFDMA and MU-MIMO enhancements.

queue_pkts.notes: Optimized buffer management for multiple simultaneous clients.

jitter_ms.notes: Significantly improved over previous Wi-Fi generations.

band_mbps.notes: Singapore ranks 1st globally with exceptional fiber infrastructure and high investment in connectivity.

delay_ms.notes: Extremely low latency due to advanced infrastructure and Singapore's strategic position as a regional internet hub.

loss_percent.notes: Very low packet loss due to high-quality infrastructure and short transmission distances.

queue_pkts.notes: Large buffer sizes to accommodate high bandwidth applications and traffic spikes.

low_queue_pkts.notes: Minimum buffer allocation optimized for high-throughput networks.

jitter_ms.notes: Minimal jitter due to consistent routing and high-quality infrastructure.

band_mbps.notes: Greece ranks 93rd globally with ongoing infrastructure improvements in urban areas.

delay_ms.notes: Moderate latency affected by geographic location and varying infrastructure quality.

loss_percent.notes: Moderate packet loss due to mixed infrastructure quality and ongoing network upgrades.

queue_pkts.notes: Medium buffer sizes reflecting moderate bandwidth requirements.

low_queue_pkts.notes: Minimum buffer allocation for moderate-throughput networks.

jitter_ms.notes: Moderate jitter due to varying infrastructure quality across regions.

band_mbps.notes: Cuba ranks 154th globally with limited infrastructure and international connectivity constraints.

delay_ms.notes: High latency due to limited international connectivity and aging infrastructure.

loss_percent.notes: Significant packet loss due to congestion and limited infrastructure capacity.

queue_pkts.notes: Smaller buffer sizes reflecting limited bandwidth and infrastructure constraints.

low_queue_pkts.notes: Minimum buffer allocation for low-throughput networks.

jitter_ms.notes: High jitter due to network congestion and varying infrastructure quality.
